div.note: The Cook's Tale is interrupted by a booklet/quire containing Gamelyn in a muchlater hand, numbered 55a1r - 55a-8v.
div.l: Of a ꝓproverbe that seith this same woord
Wele better is roten̄ Apple out of hoord
Than þᵗat he rote all þe remenaunt
So fareth it by a ryotous s̉eruaunt
It is full lesse harme to lette hym passe
Than he shend all þe ʆseruauntes in þe place
Therfore his maister yave hym acquitaunce
And bade hym go wᵗith sorow and wᵗith myschaunce
And þus this ioly prentys hade his leve
Now let hym ryotte all þe nyght or leve
And for there is no theef wᵗithout a lowke
That helpeth hym to waast and to sowke
Of that he brybe can̄ or borow may
Anoon̄ he sent his bedde and his array
Vn to a Compere / of his owen̄ sorte
That loued dys riotte and desporte
And hade a wyf þat held for countenᵃaunce
A Shop̄ / and swyfed for hir sustenaunce
Thus endeth the Cokes tale

and here folowen̄ þe
wordes bitwene the hoost / and the man of lawe
Oure hoost sawe wele that the bright sonne
The arke of his artificiaƚƚ day hath ronne
The iiiiᵗʰ part and half an houre and more
And though he were nat depe stirte in lore
He wist it was the xxviiiᵗʰ day
Of Apriƚƚ that is messager to May
And saugh wele þat þe shadow of eủery tree
Was as in length the same quantitee
That was the body erect þat caused it
And therfore by the shadow he told his wit
That Phebus which þᵗat shone so clere and bright
Degrees was xlv clombe on̄ hight
And for that day as in þat latitude
It was atte cloke he gan̄ conclude
And sodenly he plight his hors abou
